SEARCH
Package ca.jolt.form

Class FieldValidator

java.lang.Object
ca.jolt.form.FieldValidator
public final class FieldValidator extends Object
A class that encapsulates validation logic for a single form field.

Each FieldValidator is associated with exactly one field name in a Form. It maintains:

  • A list of Rule objects representing validation checks.
  • A list of UnaryOperator transformations that may alter or clean the field value before validation (e.g., trimming whitespace, changing case, etc.).
  • An optional condition Predicate that determines whether validation should run at all, based on other form values.
  • An optional valueType (e.g., Integer, Double, Boolean), indicating how this field should be interpreted.

Usage Example: 


 form.field("username")
         .required()
         .minLength(3)
         .toLowerCase()
         .when(allValues -> allValues.get("role").equals("user"));

When the verify() method is called (typically via the formâ€™s Form.verify(String[]) or Form.verifyAsync(String[])), the field's value undergoes the specified transformations, then each registered Rule runs in order. If any rule fails, an error is recorded in the parent form.

Since:
1.0
Author:
William

      public FieldValidator when(Predicate<Map<String,String>> condition)
      Sets a condition that determines whether this validator should run. If the condition evaluates to false, validation is skipped for this field.
      Parameters:
      condition - A predicate accepting all field values to decide if validation applies
      Returns:
      This FieldValidator (for fluent chaining)

    • verify

      public boolean verify()
      Verifies the current field's value against its own rules.

      This method applies any registered transformers to the field value, updates the value in the parent form, and then runs each attached rule. If any rule fails, an error is added to the parent form and false is returned; otherwise, true is returned.

      Returns:
      true if the field passes all validations; false otherwise
